reviewText:
Hitman: Codename 47... Hitman 1...

This is an Interesting game from a Series that I have only just started getting into, I have always been interested in how far my favourite games have come from their source material; the first Hitman game I played was Hitman Blood Money and I loved it, and I was suprised on how many of the elements present in that game were not in this one.

The Beauty of Blood Money was the fact that the game could be played in pretty much any way you wanted; you could play stealthily, you could tactically pacify everyone one by one, or you could just shoot everyone. C47 however can't seem to decide on how it want's to be played, you can't really play stealthily because guards will shoot you for sneezing wrong, you can't pacify everyone because there is no non-lethal wasy of getting rid of guards, and you can't just shoot everyone because you die too quickly.

There is always one or two ways to beat a level as opposed to the large playground environments used in Blood Money, without a walkthrough you will be stuck on this game often leading to cases of unfair difficulty.

Am I saying that C47 is a bad game though? No. It is simply a game that has aged poorly in several ways; the control for example is bizzare: the walk forward and run forward functions are seperate buttons. Graphically the game looks really good for 2000's standards and there are some familiar elements in this game present in future installments such as the fibre wire and Sniper rifle suitcase. You are not punished for killing enemy mooks but you are for innocent civilians, a level of frustration is reached in certain levels however when you are forced into a shootout because there is no other way around the level.

It isn't really fair to judge C47 on superior sequels, but rather look at the game itself, it isn't a bad game, but certainly not a great one, I would only reccomend this to people who have played future installments of the Franchise who want to play this out of Morbid Curiosity

FINAL VERDICT: Average

reviewText:
Well, this series got off on a shaky start. If you are looking to get into the Hitman series and want to start at the beginning, you may or may not want to skip this one anyway.

To start off, the graphics look great for the time, even though the draw distance is fairly low. Also, on more modern systems, you need to mess with the graphics options a bit so static textures don't behave like animated .gif files. Before even touching control configuration or resolution settings, make sure to set the renderer to OpenGL, no matter what. Otherwise, on a presentation level, Hitman does it's job.

As for controls, they definitely take a bit of getting used to, and you'll definitely also have to mess with the controls for at least 20 minutes just to see what suits you. And some of the design choices for them, even for the time, don't make a whole lot of sense. Such as a dedicated sprint foreword key. Luckily, after at least five or so configuration changes, I managed.

Regarding sound, the music does a pretty good job most of the time at setting the mood. Whether things are tense and you are sneaking up on your main target to slice their throat without making a peep, or running through a Columbian jungle running-and-gunning, Jasper Kyd did a solid job composing it.

On a story level, the first Hitman is a bit basic, but still captivating enough to see through to the end. One thing that really spiced my interest is the references to movies such as Scarface or The Godfather.

And finally gameplay, well, it's a lot of trial-and-error. On many missions you will find frustration as the game expects you to sit though hours and hours of you dying from the same problem when the solution was literally in the last place you would look. I really can't blame anyone for looking up a guide or walkthrough for the game, as it really doesn't give you a clue sometimes. And in regards to the missions, there are not a lot of them, so this trial-and-error frustration doesn't last too long. Some can range heavily in length and aggravation, and most aren't very replayable or memorable. There is a difference between a proper lack of hand-holding (i.e. something akin to Metroid) and tedious bull$hit.

What also range between missions are the bugs. Yes, this 14 year old game that they are still selling on Steam still has bugs. None of them are necessarily game-breaking, but can ruin a would-be successful play through a mission. Some range from minor visual glitches, to enemies that spawn out of nowhere that somehow see through your disguise and murder you, to the game spontaneously crashing.

In the end, for IO Interactive's first game, and it being the year 2000 when it was released, I give it a bit of leeway. And as a whole it isn't a bad game. I have to agree with the Metacritic score of 73/100 it was given.

If you really want to start Hitman from the ground up and are willing to deal with a bit of annoying cr@p here and there, maybe wait for a sale unless you are really that eager.

OG Triple OG OG Triple
The Original Gangster. The First Hitman game (Hitman: Codename 47) took the gaming world by storm when it came out in 2000 and remains a cult classic to this day.

Campaign: One of the finest Stealth / Strategy RPG's of its generation, it puts you in the role of Agent 47, a shadowy assassin who is equally capable of slipping in and out of target locations un-noticed as he is of pulling out a pair of chrome-plated 'Ballers' and taking absolutely everyone out. With a broad range of missions from the 'Lee Hong Assassination' (Rooftop Sniper takedown) to the 'Massacre at the Cheung Chow Fish House' (No one comes out alive), the game provides a wealth of memorable situations you will talk about years down the road.

Flaws: The game is not without its flaws - for a game nearly 14 years old, gameplay mechanics can be somewhat clunky. Probably the biggest gripe however is the in-game Save option, which does not exist. If you are spotted in the middle of a mission or die, you will need to start the mission over. While not a big issue in the earlier (shorter) missions, this can become extremely frustrating on the later missions where you need to navigate a huge mansion with tons of guards and after 20 minutes of perfection, one mis-step means you're killed and need to restart.

Do not let the gripes stop you from playing this classic which spawned 5 sequels and a movie to boot. This is the OG, the Original Hitman - where stealth, strategy and patience are virtues and the reward is the perfect hit.   Rated - (8/10)

At the time of this writing Hitman: Codename 47 is closing in on being 15 years old.

Hitman: Codename 47 has a great concept. It is the first hitman game I have played and has the series' iconic game mechanic of changing clothes which I found to be very fun. Sadly, that was one of the only things fun about this game.
The game maintains a level of enjoyment throughout except during longer missions where everything goes horrible every possible time for the player.

This game is a stealth game but often times I came to realize that the game doesnt seem to understand what a stealth game should be. Often times Agent 47 is forced into shootouts or situations that cannot be stealthed through. This becomes frustating very fast as the game also has no checkpoints and Agent 47 is relatively fragile compared to most action heroes. This lack of checkpoints makes the game challenging but less fun. Mechanics sometimes further amplify this problem as controls are imprecise and patroling guards sometimes randomly know you are the mysterious man who killed someone 2 blocks away in that back alley that no one saw or heard anything from.  The game does feature a respawn mechanic which allows the player to come back to life at a preset area (usually where you completed your last objective) ; HOWEVER, it does not make you incognito and every guard that was shooting at you before will still be shooting at you now.

The AI is terrible (Its understandable given the game is 15 years old)
Sometimes guards will be overly suspicious for no apparent reason. It is not unusual for a guard to hear a silent takedown and come running around the corner to see you over the body.. but because it was a silent takedown he obviously doesn't know it is you that performed the act. You can easily outsmart the AI but sometimes the game doesn't play by its own rules and someone downstairs three rooms away heard you when the guy right infront of you didn't.

The rules / game mechanics are vague
Even now after beating the game and understanding the game a whole lot more than I did while playing it, I do not understand the rules of some AI or mission objectives. Often times the game throws you into a level with an absurdly vague objective and lets you wander to figure it out. Usually what you are supposed to do has very little to do with the information you were given or objectives are exponentialy more complicated than the brief mission objectives say. Mission objectives do not tell you if you have completed them or not leading to sometimes trying to leave a mission and not knowing why you cannot. Often times I have wandered into an area that gets me killed not knowing it was restricted access or worse guards only sometimes care which leads to situations where you play the exact same way twice with different results.

The difficulty
Overall the game is challenging, but its a stealth game and getting caught is bad and gets you killed. Even ignoring the other flaws in the game the difficulty is still absurd. Missions can sometimes be really short and easy and then immediately you are thrown into a half hour minimum warzone with no idea what to do. Some missions I beat on my first try with no assistance from any walkthroughs and other missions even with walkthroughs it took me 5+ hours to beat a single mission. The first mission was almost impossible despite being incredibly straight forward. The first major assassination that takes place at a seaside restaurant is potentially the hardest. A later mission you are forced to take on a boss battle with Scarface Tony Montana who has an M60 while you have whatever little toy guns you can find lying around AND this is also in the middle of a larger mission where if you die you have to start all over due to no checkpoints.

Final Thoughts
Overall the game isn't the worst experience of my life. Some missions in it may qualify for that title but the game overall is enjoyable. If you had checkpoints and could skip levels that were overly hard and long the game might actually be somewhat recommendable. I think the games age does play a part in why it was so hard but a little extra effort to explain details of what needed to be done would have gone a long way in making this game a much more enjoyable experience.

At full price, I can only recommend buying Codename 47 if you're a huge Hitman enthusiast. If it's on sale, however, I highly recommend to anybody who's into the Hitman series, or anybody who wants to get into the series. Does that mean this game is awful? reviewText:
Hitman Codename 47 puts you in the shoes of a born and bred assassin and sends you off after a variety of bad guy targets in a surprisingly open environment that lets you pick and choose how you will go about dispatching death this day.

You start off waking in a hospital gown, in a cramped room somewhere out in the world, the only hints to your identity a bar-code stamped at the back of your head and a computer chip in your brain. You are then quickly taken through a series of training exercises and then given your first assignment. You never ask why, nor question who it is that sends you on these missions. You simply are a hitman, devoid of any ethical dilemmas or personal identity. As you progress through the story you will eventually begin to discover clues as to your origin but for now, there are people alive that shouldn't be.

Each mission sets you into a open area with guards, civilians, cops and others roaming the place. Various events within the missions are timed, as your targets goes about their business and it's up to you to pick the time, place and method by which you dispatch them. Different missions provide different obstacles and while all the missions have a path of least resistance you will often find yourself experimenting with different plans.

Which weapons and items you bring with you is chosen at the start of the mission at a fee although you can also pick up and use what you find throughout the mission as well as take the clothes of any unfortunate henchmen or passerby you happen to kill or incapacitate and although it requires some effort to get past the suspension of disbelief it requires when a 7ft. blad psycho with a bar-code tattoo on the back of his head passes for an oriental chef with only a change of shirts the mechanic works wonderfully in the game and the many disguises and the various places they allow you to go opens up many more avenues leading towards your target.

In general the open-ended nature of the missions is what separates Hitman 47 from the pack. An early mission has you recreating the classic Sollozzo assassination from the Godfather movie. You can play along with the movie, stashing a gun in toilet, go to the meeting, excuse yourself and then come out shooting. You can also walk through the front door with your gun cocked taking out the targets henchmen first, or you can wait for the target to go to bathroom himself and shoot him through the window, or one of a myriad of other possibilities that the game gives you.

The game looks stunning for it's time, with high quality graphics and textures. The maps are big but never devoid of life. Sound quality is acceptable but nothing out of the ordinary.

It is not all roses however, the game hasn't aged well and what was great graphics back in the day is now all but unplayable to a modern audience. The lack of a proper save game function was not acceptable, even back then.

All in all Hitman Codename 47 is a great experience, the open maps and the many paths to chose from makes this one of the few true assassination games. A definite buy for any fans of stealth and subterfuge.

Playing this is a clear sign of how far the Hitman series has come in regards to improving its gameplay. This game is riddled with problems that honestly I'm surprised I kept playing it all the way until the end. In theory, this game gives you objectives and then lets you figure out how to handle them. In practice however, the levels only really allow for one specific strategy in order to complete them. It ends up becoming a game that, rather than being about finding creative ways to brutally kill people, is really just about figuring out what you exactly must do to finish the level and then executing it.

So there's basically no variation. Also the AI is beyond terrible. I've shot guards and, so long as nobody saw me shoot them, I could stand right next to the body as the guards run up to investigate without thinking that I was the one who did it. I suppose I should be grateful about this though, because you need to kill plenty of people to finish each level. And if you get caught, expect to end up in a massive gunfight that you can have serious trouble surviving. A single witness or one unsilenced gunshot can ruin everything. Sadly, while there are a few levels that truly allow you to be a sneaky hitman, there are more levels where you are just gunning people down. And the last level doesn't even try: it's a straight shootout without any chance for subtle tactics.

If you want to be a sneaky assassin, this is not the game for you. This game's only real value at this point is that it messed up enough that the game developers had to learn from the mistakes made here. And that led to them making the fantastic Hitman: Blood Money.

But there's no real reason to play this one. Save your money and your time.

reviewText:
Hitman: Codename 47
TL;DR - Skip this, buy the second game

I would like to start off by saying that, as of writing this review, I have played every Hitman game, with the exception of Contracts. This gives me the opportunity to compare the games with each other and how well they (still) hold up.

Unfortunately, “Hitman: Codename 47” does not hold up very much. Time was not very kind to the game and it surely hasn’t aged all too well, making it rather difficult to recommend a playthrough.

There are a number of issues that plaque Codename 47. Being made 2000, it sure looks and plays like a contemporary game of that era. The graphics are okay at best, but like many early 3D games, everything is kind of blocky, which might be the result of IO-Interactive being a very small developer with limited resources back in the day. The gameplay is just plain clunky and overly complicated for no apparent reason. Seriously, different buttons for normal walking speed and running, sidestepping (strafing) and turning around? It took a while and a lot of key rebinding to get used to these controls personally. Anyone who played other or modern FPS/TPS will likely have the same issue.

Regarding the music, it’s good. Jesper Kyd, whom you may know as the composer for other games such as Assassin’s Creed, Borderlands and Kane & Lynch, is doing a fantastic job with very ambient, moody pieces, setting a perfect tone to a gritty game full of wetwork. The sound engineering in general is okay, nothing to complain about.

However, the voice acting is atrocious. Thank god they casted people with their respective dialect to fit the correlating character, but none of them are any good. Especially Agent 47 himself sounds just really silly and it’s hard to take him serious. Then again, a lot of games had this problem and still have, so it’s hard to fault the game just on the VA alone. David Bateson, voice actor for 47, reprised his role in subsequent sequels, doing a lot better in those thankfully.

Now, the biggest problem with “Codename 47” is simple: it just isn’t very good. What first appears to be a game about being sneaky and confronting targets with care and silence quickly just turns into a game that feels like a run-and-gun shooter, a pretty bad one. With the exception of two or three missions, the most part of the game is spent on gunning down the henchmen of your targets, before executing the targets themselves. Normally I don’t have a problem with blasting my way through waves of bad guys, however the problem here is A) we’re supposed to be a silent killer, so what gives? And B) the enemies have an unforgiving pin-point accuracy, leaving you dead before you can even insult the game for the cheap enemy fire.

Things that are supposed to aid you in your quest are meaningless. Taking on disguises of dispatched enemies often times doesn’t work in your favor, simply raising an alarm for the AI, which, in this game means “Everyone knows who you are, even in disguise. Why? Because the game hates you”. The AI WILL see you, disguise or not, from across the map. They will follow you, find you and they will kill you, because apparently everyone absolved with a diploma from the Liam Neeson School Of Premeditated Murder. And did I mention some missions have a failstate? So when the alarm is raised, you’re pretty much out of luck and will have to restart the mission if you’re not quick enough to get to your target. Simply put, the AI is broken beyond belief and leaves a bitter taste on an otherwise promising game.

Although I’ve been very critical about “Codename 47”, I want to address that I’ve had my fair share of fun with it. I loathed it more than enjoying it, but I would be lying if I didn’t enjoy some aspects, like the few missions which feel like actual Hitman games (the missions “The Lee Hong Assassination” and “Traditions of the Trade” come to mind).

“Hitman: Codename 74” sets the foundations for a fantastic and still mostly unique video game franchises. The debut game is sadly overshadowed by subsequent games in every conceivable way. With the second game in the series, “Silent Assassin”, IO-Interactive out-done themselves already.

If you would like to know how the franchise started, give it try. However, if you want to play a game that feels more like a proper Hitman, skip this one and just continue with the second game, Silent Assassin. Otherwise, try “Hitman: Contracts” which is basically an expanding and proper remake of the debut.

Well, I probably will get minuses for this, but I just can't lie about it.

Original Hitman was one of the games of my childhood. This was the first assassin-theme game I ever played. I instantly got into it, and carried out a little obsession with assassin's, thieves, spies and other people of that kind to present days.  So it was fun back then, I even recall a moment when I called a friend to help me figure out the level, sweet memories.

The reason behind negative review is because we became spoiled. Times back then we didn't had that much variety of games and stuff we have now. Games like this was jewels. When I came back to this, I haven't got even half of the fun I had back then. This game have alot of problems. It all begins with a some bugs and glitches and end up in sometimes just terrible level design. Some events have no logic behind it, like say a mission in harbour, when a guy comes up from guarded doors, you can kill him and take his clothes, but guards still won't let you in for some reason. Beside all this, the game is relentless - you will die in a matter of seconds even on low difficulty. You of course have a restarts, but they have a little sense, since the guards already know that they need to kill you, and so you die, again. To a matter of fact, enemies sometime attack you out of spite, with no reason behind it, and you will have to replay level all over again coz' game only saves between levels. Also, why they would give you immense amount of money, when you can't even spent 1/4 of them, even if you buy everything on every mission.

This all leads to a complete frustration - the game you might admired so much back then doesn't seem so good anymore. To enjoy this game you need to get a time machine, otherwise it's just not worth it. Returning players may get some nostalgia out of it, but it will remain good if you won't push yourself. Newcomers might aswell read the plot and move on to the next part, which is alot more better in every way.

reviewText:
Summary
One of the finest examples of semi-open world assassination simulation.

Hitman; Codename 47 is primitive in objective and aim, your goal is to simply assassinate your enemy and to destroy or collect items relevant to him - with any means necessary!

Plot
Codename 640509-040147 is the designation given by the Prof. Dr. Otto Wolfgang Ort-Meyer a German scientist who worked on the genetics to create the world's best assassinator, with the recombinant DNA of 5 fathers all belonging to criminal overlords known as; Otto Wolfgang Ort-Meyer himself, Chinese restraunt owner Lee Hong, Columbian drug lord Pablo Belisario Ochoa, International terrorist Franz Fuchs and finally Arkadij Jegorov, a international gun launderer from Kazakhstan. Agent 47, his demeanour is cold, calculative and as sharp as a .338 Lapua Magnum round in your Cerebral Cortex, is set out to join the ICA, his base of operations that deliver him contracts to take up in assassinating his marks for money, however the marks set by his client may not be exactly say who he actually is.

Gameplay
The gameplay in Hitman Codename 47 places you in an open area with different places to execute killshots or strangulate your mark. Killing too many civilians will severely reduce your paygrade and the ability to purchase ammo and other equipment for the job and committing mass murder of innocents will inevitable cause you to fail the mission.

Graphics
This game features radiosity shadowing, high polygon counts and high resolution textures and use of physics ragdolls which were impressive for their time (near 2000). Though the repetition in the use of urban buildings is overused and the sprite/flat shaded sprites and textures for foilage are not very well done. The draw distance is terrible

Sound
The games audio has high use of fidelity (16 bit, 48Khz was considerably high) in its soundtracks and is focused mainly on its theme which has a Jungle and Classical genre feel to it, sound effects are done to great effect, representing a solid bullet shot out of a Sniper Rifle into the flesh of someones face.

The original story about the worlds best Hitman, is a difficult one, but worth it.

Outdated graphics, controls and gameplay are all bearable, but the reward is hours of fun. And frustration at the Scarface reference. The game gives you many options to complete your objective, some of which are not as obvious or easy to execute as others, so you start experimenting while carefully weighing risk versus gain, since there is no save function.
If you die, you restart the level.

To the end, missions get more complex and way more difficult, so difficult, that at one point I had to abuse the AI and wait with a drawn gun behind a door, waiting for the enemies to parse through it one by one.

Compared to newer games (Hitman: Absolution for example), this game is worse looking, has clunkier controls, but gameplay that is a thousand times better than Absolution.

That said though, if you want the best Hitman experience, get Hitman: Blood Money. You can skip Hitman: Silent Assassin and you should most definitely skip Hitman: Absolution.

Hitman: Codename 47 had freaking awesome visuals for a 2000 release and the music is most definitely by Jesper Kyd but at the same time the combat feels clunky, the voice acting is completely lifeless and the mission design itself is lacklustre and not very player friendly. What saddens me the most is that many of the levels and story elements explored in the first Hitman are replayable in the vastly superior Hitman Contracts, which is also on PC. Great. Except there is one problem: Hitman Contracts isn't available on Steam. Damn.

reviewText:
This game can be very difficult, and the things you need to pull off can be obscure and vague at best at times. However, its not exactly bad, just a bit poorly executed. Also the interface is fairly bad (I'm looking at YOU map!).

Unfortunately the game doesn't work on a quicksave/quickload system like a lot of FPS'/ later Hitman games, oh no. It works on limited checkpoint system that just respawns you at a certain point you got up to, without actually altering your progress made from up to that point. So lets say you bite the dust whilst having alerted every damn enemy in the map. They will STILL BE ALERTED. And a lot of the time, if you alert everyone and don't do something about it FAST, your main target will be alerted and he will haul it out of there faster than you can say game over.

I only beat about 3 levels before it got to the point where the game just got too hard and annoying for me. I just honestly gave up and just watched someone else play the rest of the game via the internets, and had no regrets in doing so. A lot of the things you have to do looks obscure and hard to pull off.

Later Hitman games are much more playable, so I suggest you ignore this one at first unless you have absurd amounts of patience, wit, and skill.

The Original Hitman, what can I say.

The Game plays extremely frustrating, but beating a level is a lot more rewarding than in most games nowadays.
Hitman wants to be hard enough to realize that killing people is indeed -not- a game but a hard job that can claim your own life easily. Something most shooters are lacking for instance. Hitman carries on the tradition of Thief, where intelligent stealth and planning of your equipment beats the loadout you are carrying.

And here starts the pain:
Stealth is nothing you just do, it is a hard earned skill of knowing what to do and when. Sometimes this means a Minute or two of simply doing -nothing- waiting, pacing and taking your time. Sometimes Stealth means being really quick and just not missing the right moment. Most of the Time Stealth means: Use one bullet max, the rest is knifework.

These lessons are hard taught in C47 and none of it´s successors retaliates so hard on missing out on any relevant detail. On the other hand you realy have a feeling of -beating- the game and not just dangling along.

This is why I enjoyed it just like Thief, back in the days, and am learning the hard way, that a lot of my patience and skills from back then have given way to a happy triggerfinger, which is needed a lot more in other games.

To Wrap things up:
C47 was clearly ahead of it´s time gameplay wise and it is still a challenge to beat.
The Risk and Reward system really works well and the frustration level for tiny misteps is enormous, as you wont be able to save a level.
It is just like going by Yoda: Do, or do not! There is no try!

reviewText:
The Story: You awaken in what appears to be a cell, which is in one of those lovely sanatorium's. There is a loudspeaker instructing you to do various tasks from putting your clothes on, scaling obstacles and using firearms to become an efficient assassin. Now after completing all the tasks you end up escaping from the sanatorium. Later on about you aka subject 47 end up as a professional hitman of the International Contract Agency (ICA), now known as Agent 47. He is briefed by his handler, Diana Burnwood, and sent around the globe to eliminate four criminal masterminds with large enterprises, companies and crews. You gradually go through the missions, learning as you go. To an interesting end for that part of this game series.

Game play: Hitman Codename 47 is played in a third-person perspective with a control setup is similar to a first person shooter. Each level is an open environment which is populated with NPC's such as civilians and armed guards. Now basically you as Agent 47. Carry out your assignments, which usually is to kill some one. But they can be other things your are told to do. Some may say the paths may appear linear in the game. But that is wrong there is many different ways you can accomplish your missions. But the game essentially emphasises stealth and silent kills without raising alerts, giving the player a higher financial reward for doing so. Penalties in the form of financial deductions are given, for example if the player kills civilians.

Disguise plays a large role in gameplay. Any NPC that Agent 47 (You) kills you can take their clothes which can help you in completing the mission. But you must also make sure no on finds that body or you disguise will be useless. So there is alot to the game play of this game which makes it a fun game to play in the Hitman Series.

The Graphics: Well if you compare them to the graphics we have they do not even stand a chance. But for the graphics back then when the game came out. They were certainly good. Even now I can still play it with how it looks.

Controls: Simple mouse and keyboard setup. You can customize your key to suit you.

The Music: What can I say the music with this is just works right in my view. It always had held a place in this gamers heart in the Hitman Series.

The Reply Value: Unless you wish to try possible different ways to do each mission. There is not much reply value.

Bugs/Glitches: Well back then I don't remember seeing any issues with the game. But now there is some. Due to the game not really made to work properly on higher OS's than when it came out. But don't let that stop you. There is fixes for start up issues on the Steam and GOG forums.

Overall: Story had me intrigued right up to the end. The game play is just right for this type of game, even for my psycho style I play some times. Graphics as I said good for when the game came out. But certainly couldn't hold a candle to today's. But that certainly didn't stop me from playing it. Controls simple easy to configure, what more could you ask for. Music just right for the game. Reply value it is there but not alot. Bugs/Glitches as I said for new OS/Systems yes, but there is fixes out there. So taking in the everything even when the game came out. I give this a 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
The Original Hitman, what can I say.

The Game plays extremely frustrating, but beating a level is a lot more rewarding than in most games nowadays.
Hitman wants to be hard enough to realize that killing people is indeed -not- a game but a hard job that can claim your own life easily. Something most shooters are lacking for instance. Hitman carries on the tradition of Thief, where intelligent stealth and planning of your equipment beats the loadout you are carrying.

And here starts the pain:
Stealth is nothing you just do, it is a hard earned skill of knowing what to do and when. Sometimes this means a Minute or two of simply doing -nothing- waiting, pacing and taking your time. Sometimes Stealth means being really quick and just not missing the right moment. Most of the Time Stealth means: Use one bullet max, the rest is knifework.

These lessons are hard taught in C47 and none of it´s successors retaliates so hard on missing out on any relevant detail. On the other hand you realy have a feeling of -beating- the game and not just dangling along.

This is why I enjoyed it just like Thief, back in the days, and am learning the hard way, that a lot of my patience and skills from back then have given way to a happy triggerfinger, which is needed a lot more in other games.

To Wrap things up:
C47 was clearly ahead of it´s time gameplay wise and it is still a challenge to beat.
The Risk and Reward system really works well and the frustration level for tiny misteps is enormous, as you wont be able to save a level.
It is just like going by Yoda: Do, or do not! There is no try!

reviewText: Although there were definitely many flaws to this game, it was still incredibly fun to play and I was always challenged on every single mission. Probably the worst part of the game was the inability to save your progress in a mission. There was a checkpoint system in place, but if the guards were alerted before you died the first time, they would remain so when you respawned at a checkpoint. Furthermore, the difficulty of this game doesn't really allow for you to alert the guards very much. You pretty much have to be stealthy or very strategic when killing guards because their bullets do massive damage to your health, even on normal difficulty. Some of the missions are incredibly long as well, and many of them include large amounts of running before you can even encountering your objectives. Therefore, if you screwed up, it can cost you about 5 minutes of running around before you can get back to where you were. Other than that, the game is great. The weapons are fun to use, the stealth system is pretty solid, the missions are unique and well thought out. Most missions have multiple approaches of taking out a target, but most are fairly difficult to find. Other than the name and general location of the target, the game really doesn't help you out in terms of hints and clues. If you aren't very good at problem solving like me, you may have to use a guide to give you an idea of what to do in some of the more tricky missions. Overall, though, this game is challenging and entertaining and a good introduction to the Hitman series

reviewText:
This review is mostly based on previous experiences of the game. I picked it up again as part of a bundle, and thinking that maybe I remembered it to be worse than it was gave it a go. But no, nope, it's it's actually the opposite. Hitman didn't deserve a positive rating back when it was released, and it certainly doesn't deserve it now.

The UI of the game is absolutely atrocious, and your biggest enemy in the game are the controls. In a design decision that inexplicaply persisted all the way up to Blood Money, all functions are hidden under a handful of keys, and if several tied to the same one are performable at a given moment, you have to CYCLE THROUGH A DROP DOWN MENU to get to the correct one. As difference between success and death -- which incidentally means you have to start the mission from the start, as there is no possibility of saving -- often comes down to seconds, you will often see your master assassin dead because he couldn't figure out how to work the elevator or holster his weapon in time.

The missions, meanwhile, are furstrating grind. Unlike in the later games, you will not be given enough information beforehand to plan a course of action, nor the opportunity to observe your surroundings to decide one. The ONLY way to complete the missions is to do them over and over again until you find just the right sequence of actions and are able to execute it to the dot. The issue is compounded by the ridiculously unpredictable physics of the game: Invisible walls, knee-high barriers you can't vault, handguns that send corpses flying over buildings. And after all this, there is ultimately little reward for completing the missions, as the story of the game is little more than an excuse thereof. The writing is bad, the voice-acting worse, and the graphics haven't exactly aged gracefully, either. Avoid at all cost.

It's graphics are bad but for the year 2000, what are you going to do? For the time especially they are amazing. But let's focus on some things I don't particularly like about this game. The controls are AWFUL, at least until you set them up... Then they get, better but still quite difficult to get used to. The animations are, different. They completely over exaggerate their arms and legs and torsos... It's fun to watch so 10 points there. There aren't really any other bad things I can say about this game, except really anything bad about the others that this shares... Either way, I still recommend this game. If you haven't played any Hitman games before, start with this one. It explains the story a bit more than the others do.

The AI is wonky at times and is easily exploited presenting a certain level of difficulty for some missions. In the end, the game is far from perfect, but Hitman: Codename 47 is fun for the light-hearted, frivolous players of the generation.
